document.docTitle: Arundinosides I-IX and graminifolosides A-B: 2R-benzylmalate and 2R-isobutylmalates derivatives from Arundina graminifolia (D.Don) Hochr. with antioxidant, cytocompatibility and cytoprotective properties

paragraph.docTitle: Arundinosides I-IX and graminifolosides A-B: 2R-benzylmalate and 2R-isobutylmalates derivatives from Arundina graminifolia (D.Don) Hochr. with antioxidant, cytocompatibility and cytoprotective properties

subSection.paragraph: Glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -benzylmalate derivatives
Glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -isobutylmalate derivatives
Arundinosides I-IX
Graminifolosides A-B
ABSTRACT

Phytochemical investigation of the underground parts of
Arundina graminifolia D.Don Hochr
was conducted leading to the isolation of nine new glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -benzylmalate and two new glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R - isobutylmalate derivatives. The compounds were purified using chromatographic techniques and their structures were deduced based on spectroscopic techniques including nuclear magnetic resonance and high-resolution mass spectrometry as well as comparing with previous literature. The antioxidant activities of the isolated compounds were also evaluated. The compounds showed potent antioxidant activities in the ABTS radical scavenging, DPPH radical scavenging and FRAP activities. Furthermore, the isolated compounds were observed to exert minimal cytotoxic effects against RAW 264.7 cell, suggesting biocompatibility as well as cytoprotective effects against hydrogen peroxide induced cell toxicity.

Glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -benzylmalate and glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -isobutylmalate derivatives are structurally unique group of plant metabolites that occurs primarily in the family Orchidaceae . There are very limited studies reporting this class of compounds due to their rare occurrence in nature.
Arundina graminifolia D.Don Hochr. (Orchidaceae)
popularly known as bamboo orchid is widely distributed in subtropical Asia, particularly in South East Asian countries. It is a terrestrially growing orchid accepted as the only species in the genus ( Hong et al., 1983 ; Gao et al., 2012 ). In China , the plant is found in Fujian , Yunnan , Zhejiang , Jiangxi , Guangdong and Sichuan provinces and it is popularly used as alone or in combination with other medicinal plants by the Bulang, Dai and Wa ethic groups. Traditionally,
A. graminifolia D.Don Hochr
is popular as an antidote for food and drug poisoning by the Dai ethnic group and it is one of the important ingredients found in several medicinal preparations because of the characteristic detoxification theory of the Dai ethnic group of “relieving before cure”. In addition,
A. graminifolia D.Don Hochr
is considered in Traditional Chinese Medicine as a drug that is effective for heat clearance, pain alleviation, eliminating wind and dampness ( Zhang et al., 2021 ). Furthermore, the roots/rhizomes and leaves of the plant are used for treating blood stasis and liver detoxification, pulmonary infection, beriberi edema, rheumatism, snakebites, traumatic injuries and as a skin moisturizer ( Zhang et al., 2021 ; Gao et al., 2012 ; Hossain, 2009 , 2011 ). This plant is known to be a rich source of bibenzyls ( Majumder and Ghosal, 1994 ; Liu et al., 2004 ; Du et al., 2014 ), phenanthrenes ( Liu et al., 2005a ,b; Liu et al., 2005a ,b), phenolic ( Gao et al., 2012 ; Hu et al., 2013 ; Li et al., 2013 ; Shu

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Strasbourg, 67400, Illkirch-Graffenstaden, France .
1 Passed away before the manuscript was submitted for publication.

subSection.paragraph:
et al., 2013) and glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -benzylmalate derivatives ( Auberon et al., 2018 , 2019 , 2020 ; Liu et al., 2019a ,b) with several pharmacological activities including antibacterial, antiviral, cytotoxic and anti-liver fibrotic effects. As a furtherance to the studies on the bioactive constituents from
A. graminifolia D.Don Hochr
, nine new glucosyloxybenzyl 2R-benzylmalate, arundinosides I-IX (1–9) and two new glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -isobutylmalates, graminifolosides A-B (10–11) were isolated and identified from the underground part of the plant.

document.paragraph: 1H (500 MHz, methanol-d4) and 13C (125 MHz, methanol-d4) NMR data of arundinosides I-III

subSection.paragraph:
Arundinoside I (1) was obtained as a white amorphous powder with the molecular formula of C 38 H 46 O 20 , which was determined from the HRESIMS at m/z 840.2915 [M + NH 4 ] + . The 13 C NMR data showed resonances corresponding to 34 carbons; including four methyls, five methylenes, nine sp 2 methines, ten sp 3 methines and six carbonyl carbons. Comparison of the NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 1 ) of 1 with those of arundinoside T, a previously isolated compound from
A . graminifolia D. Don Hochr
indicated that compound 1 shared similar structural features with it (benzylmalic acid and glucosyloxybenzyl moieties) ( Auberon et al., 2020 ). Compound 1 differs from arundioside T based on the acetyl substituent attached to C-6 ′′′ ’. The benzylmalic-glucosyloxybenzyl skeleton is composed of a benzylmalic unit [ δH / δC 3.11, 2.96 (d, J = 17.8 Hz, H-3)/44.3; 3.01, 2.94 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, H-5)/47.3; 7.02 (m, H-7/11)/132.0; 7.15 (m, H-8/10)/129.1; δC 172.7 (C-1), 82.5 (C-2), 174.0 (C-4) and 136.5 (C-6)] and a glucosyloxybenzyl unit [ δH / δC 7.28 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, H-2’/6 ′ )/131.7; 7.07 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, H-3’/5 ′ )/117.9; 5.11, 4.95 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, H-7 ′ )/67.9; 4.93 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-1 ′′′ ’)/102.3; 3.47 (m, 4 ′ - O -glc-2 ′′′ ’)/75.0; 3.47 (dd, J = 9.3, 9.3 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-3 ′′′ ’)/77.9; 3.39 (dd, J = 9.3, 9.3 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-4 ′′′ ’)/71.6; 3.66 (ddd, J = 9.3, 6.1, 2.2 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-5 ′′′ ’)/75.4; 4.24 (dd, J = 11.9, 6.1 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-6a’’’’) and 4.41 (dd, J = 11.9, 2.2 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-6b’’’’)/64.8; 2.07 (s, 6 ′′′ ’-Ac-2)/20.9; δC 131.0 (C-1 ′ ), 159.2 (C-4 ′ ) and 172.9 (C-6 ′′′ ’-Ac-1)]. The resonance of an additional acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ [ δH / δC 2.05 (s, 6 ′′′ -Ac-2/20.9; δC 172.8 (C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1)] on the glucose unit connected to C-2 of the benzylmalic unit which replaces the hydroxyl group in arundioside T was confirmed by HMBC correlations of H-6 ′′′ with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1 and H-6 ′′′ -Ac-2 with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1. The absolute configuration of 1 was determined by alkaline hydrolysis that yielded a 2R-benzymalic acid, which was identified by

25 comparison of its NMR spectroscopic data and optical rotation value [ α ]
D
75 ( c 0.2, CH 3 OH) and it was deduced as 2 R according to the configuration of previously reported arundinoside derivatives ( Auberon et al., 2018 , 2019 ; Liu et al., 2019a ,b; Tanaka et al., 1984 ; Huang et al., 2004 ). As such, the structure of arundinoside I was established as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-6-acetyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2,3,6-triacetyl)- 2 R -benzylmalic acid.

Arundinoside II (2) was also obtained as a white amorphous solid with a molecular formula of C 41 H 46 O 18 according to its HR-ESI-MS data [M-H] - ion at m/z 825.2546. Analysis of the NMR data ( Table 1 ) suggested that compound 2 was similar to compound 1, suggesting that both compounds have structural similarities (benzylmalic and glucosyloxybenzyl moieties), except for the absence of the acetyl groups at C- 3 ′′′ , C-6?and C-6 ′′′ ’. In addition, the presence of a trans -cinnamoyl moiety at δH / δC 7.64 (dd, J = 7.7, 2.1 Hz, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-2/6)/129.4; 7.42 (m, H- 3 ′′′ ’-Cin-3/5)/130.2; 7.42 (m, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-4)/131.6; 7.77 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-7)/146.5; 6.64 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-8)/119.3; δC 136.0 (C– H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-1) and 168.5 (C– H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-9) in 2 replaced the hydroxyl group at C-3 ′′′ ’ in 1. The position of the trans -cinnamoyl moiety was confirmed by HMBC correlations of H-3 ′′′ ’ and H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-7 with C-3 ′′′ ’- Cin-9, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-8 with C– H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-1 and H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-7 with C-3 ′′′ ’- Cin-2/6. The absolute configuration of 2 was determined using the same method as that of 1. Thus, arundinoside II was elucidated as 1-(ss- Dglucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3-trans-cinnamoyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2- acetyl)-2R-benzylmalic acid.

Arundinoside III (3) yielded a molecular formula of C 62 H 72 O 30 , as confirmed by the HR-ESI-MS at m/z 1314.4461 [M + NH 4 ] + . A comparison of the NMR data of 3 ( Table 1 ) with arundinoside C ( Auberon et al., 2018 ) revealed a striking structural resemblance, except the addition of an acetyl group [( δH / δC 2.04 (s, H-6 ′′′ ’-Ac-2)/21.0; δC 172.8 (C-6 ′ ′ ′ ′ -Ac-1) esterified on C-6 ′′′ ’. The absolute configuration of 3 was determined using the same method as that of 1. The absolute configuration was deduced based on the exhibited negative optical rotation ([ α ]
D
25
Table 1 ( continued )

caption.paragraph: 1H (500 MHz, methanol-d4) and 13C (125 MHz, methanol-d4) NMR data of arundinosides IV-VI

subSection.paragraph: 56 ( c 0.4, CH 3 OH)), which is consistent with a R absolute configuration and based on the biogenetic relationship as previously reported in the literature ( Auberon et al., 2018 , 2019 ; Tanaka et al., 1984 ). Therefore, arundinoside III was structurally deduced as shown and named as 1-( ss -D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-6-acetyl)-2-( ss -D-glucopyranosyl-2,3,4 -triacetyl-6- > 1–2 R -benzylmalyl)-4-( ss -D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R - benzylmalic acid.

Arundinoside IV (4) was purified as a white amorphous powder with a molecular formula of C 56 H 64 O 25 as established by the HR-ESI-MS [M- H] - ion peak at m/z 1135.3583 (calcd. for C 56 H 63 O 25 for 1135.3663). Analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectral data ( Table 2 ) of 4 suggested that the planar structure compound 4 was similar to arundinoside Z ( Auberon et al., 2020 ); one benzylmalic acid, two hydroxybenzoyl, three sugars, one acetyl group on C-2 ′′′ , one cinnamoyl group on c-3 ′′′ ’, except for the presence of an acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ ’ in 4 [ δH / δC 1.69 (s, H-2 ′′′ -Ac-2)/21.4; δC 172.7 (C-2 ′′′ -Ac-1). This was confirmed by the HMBC correlations between H-6 ′′′ ’ and C-2 ′′′ -Ac-1 and H-2 ′′′ -Ac-2 to C-2 ′′′ -Ac-1. The absolute configuration of 4 was determined using the same method as that of 1. Thus, 4 was deduced as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2- acetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid (see Fig. 1 ).
Table 2 ( continued )

Arundinoside V (5) was isolated as a white amorphous powder. The [M –H] - ion peak appeared at m/z 1135.358 (calcd. for C 56 H 63 O 25 for 1135.3663) in the HRESIMS spectrum indicated the same molecular formula of C 56 H 64 O 25 as compound 4. Apart from the absence of the acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ ’, the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 2 ) of 5 was quite similar with those of 4. The acetyl group was however positioned at C-6 ′′′ . The HMBC correlations of H-6 ′′′ with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1 and H-6 ′′′ -Ac-2 with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1 proved the position of acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ ’ (see Fig. 2 ). The absolute configuration of the benzylmalic acid (2R) was determined by using the same method employed for the previous compounds described above. Compound 5 was thus elucidated as 1-(ss- Dglucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2, 6-diacetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid.

Arundinoside VI (6) was isolated as a white amorphous solid with the same molecular formula (C 56 H 64 O 25 ) as compounds 4 and 5. The NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 2 ) of 6 showed strong resemblance to those of 5, suggesting that 6 is also a 2 R -benzylmalate derivative. The only difference between these two compounds was the absence of the acetyl group attached to C-6 ′′′ in 6 which was now positioned at C-3 ′′′ . This was confirmed by HMBC correlations of H-4 ′′′ and H-3 ′′′ -Ac-2 with C-3 ′′′ -Ac- 1. The 2 R configuration was assigned to 6 based on the negative optical rotation as previously described for other 2R-benzylmalate derivative. Arundinoside VI was proposed structurally as shown and elucidated as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2,3-diacetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid (see Fig. 3 ).

Arundinoside VII (7) had a molecular formula of C 56 H 63 O 25 deduced from its HR-ESI-MS data at m/z 1135.3542 [M-H] - (calcd. for C 56 H 63 O 25 for 1135.3663). The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectral ( Table 3 ) of 7 revealed an overall structural resemblance to 4, except for the difference in the position of the trans -cinnamoyl moiety at C-4 ′′′ ’ in 7 due to the HMBC correlations of H-4 ′′′ ’ with C-4 ′′′ ’- Cin -9. Accordingly, the structure of 7 was assigned as shown and elucidated as 1-( ss -D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-4- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-( ss -D-glucopyranosyl-2-acetyl)-4- ( ss -D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid (see Fig. 3 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Structures of the eleven isolated compounds.
Fig. 2. Key HSQC-TOCSY, COSY, HMBC and NOESY correlations of arundinosides I–V (1–5).

subSection.paragraph: Arundinoside VIII (8) showed similar 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra data ( Table 3 ) with those of 7, except for the presence of an additional acetyl group. The HRESIMS data of 8 ( m/z 1177.3715 [M-H] - ; calcd. for C 58 H 65 O 26 for 1177.3710) was consistent with the molecular formula of C 58 H 66 O 26 and the difference in the m/z values of 43 amu compared to 7. The additional acetyl group signal [ δH / δC 1.97 (s, H-6 ′′′ -Ac-2)/20.9; δC 172.9 (C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1)] in the 1 H and 13 C NMR resonances as well as HMBC cross peaks of H-6 ′′′ with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-2 confirmed that an acetyl group is substituted at C-6 ′′′ (see Fig. 3 ).. Compound 8 was therefore elucidated as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-(ss- Dglucopyranosyl-2,6-diacetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid.

Arundinoside IX (9) was assigned a molecular formula of C 63 H 68 O 25 according to the HR-ESI-MS peak at m/z 1242.4394 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd.for C 63 H 72 NO 25 for 1242.4387). The NMR data of 9 showed characteristic features of one benzylmalic acid, two glucosyloxybenzyl, three ss- Dglucose, one acetyl and two trans -cinnamoyl acid moieties. Analysis of the NMR data of 9 ( Table 3 ) showed an overall structural resemblance to arundinoside A ( Auberon et al., 2018 ),except for the presence of a hydroxyl which replaced the acetyl group at C-2?in arundinoside A. On the basis of these findings, the structure of compound 9 was identified as 1-( ss - D- glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3,4-di- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-( ss -D-glucopyranosyl)-4-( ss -D-glucopyranosyl-oxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalate (see Fig. 4 )..

Graminifoloside A (10) was purified as a white amorphous powder, with a molecular formula of C 53 H 66 O 25 based on the HR-ESI-MS: m/z 1101.3755 [M-H] - (calcd. for C 53 H 65 O 25 for 1101.3820). Comparison of the NMR data of 10 ( Table 4 ) with 7 showed similar signals, suggesting a close similarity in their structures. However, the major difference resides on the acid moiety which is an isobutylmalic acid in 10. In the 1 H NMR spectra, one methine and two methyl protons were observed at δH 1.77 (m, H-6), 0.76 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, H-7) and 0.83 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, H-8) which corresponds to the isobutylmalic acid group. This was further verified by HMBC correlations of H-7 and H-8 with C-5 and C-6 (see Fig. 4 ).. In addition, the absence of the benzylmalic signals in the 1H NMR spectra also validated this analogy. Moreover, the isobutylmalic acid moiety was established as a 2 R configuration based on the negative optical rotation which has been reported for previous derivatives ( El Bialy et al., 2005 ; Morikawa et al., 2006a ,b; Cota et al., 2008 ; Wang et al., 2013 ; Huang et al., 2002 ). Thus, the structure of graminifoloside A was elucidated as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-4- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2-ac etyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -isobutylmalic acid and structurally determined as shown.

Based on the HR-ESI-MS data m/z 1208. 1208.4513 [M + NH 4 ] + , the molecular formula of graminifoloside B (11) was deduced as C 60 H 70 O 25 . The spectroscopic data of compound 11 were very similar to those of 10. A detailed analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data revealed the presence of two glucosyloxybenzyl, three sugars and one isobutylmalic acid moieties analogous to those in compound 10. The most noticeable difference in these data were the presence of additional signals assigned to a trans - cinnamoyl moiety at C-3 ′′′ ’ in 11 ( Table 4 ). These difference were confirmed by 1 H NMR signals at δH 7.54 (m, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-2/6), 7.38 (m, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ - cin-3/5), 7.68 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-4) and 6.52 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ - cin-8) and in the 13 C NMR δC 135.6 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-1), 129.5 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-2/6), 130.2 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-3/5), 131.8 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-4), 147.3 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-7), 118.3 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ - cin-8) and 168.0 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-9). These analogies were confirmed by HMBC correlations from the H-3 ′′′ ’ with 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-9. Thus, graminifoloside B was defined as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3,4-di- trans -cinnamoyl-6- acetyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2-acetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -isobutylmalic acid.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. Key HSQC-TOCSY, COSY, HMBC and NOESY correlations of arundinosides VI-IX (6–9).

subSection.paragraph: The isolated compounds were also investigated for their cytotoxicity against macrophage (RAW 264.7) cells at a range of 3.9–500 μg/mL. The results of cytotoxicity indicated that the compounds demonstrated a dose dependent toxicity against RAW 264.7 cell. Moreover, the isolated constituents at tested concentration of ~125 μg/mL showed > 70% of cell viability. The results suggested that phyto-constituents are more biocompatible.

Oxidative stress caused by the excessive production of reactive oxygen species, results in cellular damage that leads to several diseases including aging, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases. Cellular viability was investigated after exposure to varying concentration of H 2 O 2 (1–8 mM). The results revealed a concentration dependent cell viability ( Fig. 5 ). Hydrogen peroxide has been reported to mediate cell necrosis and death in both bacterial and cell-lines through the induction of intracellular free radical generation. Exposure of RAW 264.7 cells to 3 mM of H 2 O 2 resulted in a ~60% reduction of cell viability. However, pretreatment of RAW 264.7 cells with the isolated compounds (compounds 3, 5, 6 and 8) at concentrations of 7.81–125 mg /mL resulted in cytoprotective effect against H 2 O 2 induced cell mortality. The compounds treated cells demonstrated 39–77% increase in cell viability in presence of 3.0 mM of H 2 O 2 ( Fig. 6 ). This results collaborate with antioxidant efficacy of the compounds with effective attenuations of H 2 O 2 induced oxidative stress medicated cell death.

caption.paragraph: 1H (500 MHz, methanol-d4) and 13C (125 MHz, methanol-d4) NMR data of arundinosides VII-IX.

subSection.paragraph:
In conclusion, eleven new compounds, including nine 2 R -benzylmalate derivatives designated as arundinosides I-IX (1–9) and two new 2 R -isobutylmalates derivatives designated as graminifolosides A-B (10–11) were purified from the undergrounds parts of
Arundina graminifolia D.Don Hochr.
This is the first report on the isobutylmalic acid derivatives in
A. graminifolia D.Don Hochr. It
is quite interesting to note that some orchids are able to produce this type of glucosides based on different acids (benzylmalyl and isobutyl and tartaric acid) as the pivot ( El Bialy et al., 2005 ; Kizu et al., 1999 ; Li et al., 2007 ; Morikawa et al., 2006a ,b; Sahakitpichan et al., 2013 ; Zi et al., 2008 ). The isolated compounds were tested for their antioxidant activity using DDPH, ABTS and FRAP assays. Compounds 3–8 showed antioxidant activity against DPPH (370.6–545 mmol Trolox equivalent/g sample), ABTS (543.7–1311.0 mmol Trolox equivalent/g sample) and FRAP (103.1–1098.7 mmol Trolox equivalent/g sample). Additionally, the compounds (3, 5, 6 and 8) showed cytocompatibility and cytoprotective effects in RAW macrophage cells.
All information regarding the general experimental procedures including the instruments and procedures were included in the supplementary information.

The dried roots and rhizomes of
Arundina graminifolia D.Don Hochr (Orchidaceae)
were collected in
September 2010
at Joe Orchid Farm ( Chiang Mai , Thailand , GPS 18.919048339241826, 98.93458399321969) and the voucher samples (n ◦ 05–563) of the plant were authenticated and deposited at the herbarium of the Faculty of Science , Chiang Mai University , Thailand. The importation of the plant materials to France followed the guidelines of the
Convention on International Trade
in Endangered Species
.

paragraph.emphasis: 4.4. Determination of the absolute configuration of the sugar moiety

subSection.paragraph: Simmler et al. (2011) was used for the determination of the absolute configuration of the sugar moiety. Briefly, 1 mg of the compound was solubilized 0.5 mL of 2 M HCl and subjected to reflux for 3 h. Thereafter, the solution was allowed to cool down and partitioned with n-butanol. The aqueous phase obtained after partitioning was concentrated under reduced pressure and derivatized with pyridine and 1-(trimethylsilyl) imidazole (4:1 v/v) for 60 min a temperature of 60 ◦ C. The derivatized sample was identified using a GC-MS Trace GC Ultra instrument with the following conditions: column; TR-5MS SQC (0.25 μm, 15 m × 0.25 mm ); Detection was achieved on a DSQII Thermo Scientific mass spectrometer (mass range of m/z 0 to 500). D-glucose was identified by comparing the retention time of the derivatized sample with the standard glucose.

paragraph.emphasis: 4.6. Biocompatibility studies on macrophage RAW264.7 cells

subSection.paragraph: The biocompatibility of the isolated compounds were assessed on macrophage RAW 264.7 cells. Briefly, cells procured from the Institute of Research and Innovation, Walailak University, Nakhon Si Thammarat , were cultured in high glucose RPMI-1640 supplemented with 10% of fetal bovine serum and 100 μg/mL of streptomycin and 100 U/ml penicillin solution. Approximately 4 × 105 cells were seeded in 96-well plate and incubated at 37 ◦ C with 5% CO2. After 24 h of incubation, the culture medium was replaced with fresh RPMI-1640 as negative control in triplicate, whereas DMSO was tested for solvent effect. Moreover, cells were treated with 200 μL of varying concentrations of the isolated compounds (3.9–500 μg/mL) and incubated for 24 h. The viability of cells after treatment was analyzed using MTT assay and the optical density measured at 570 nm .

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Cytotoxicity effects of the isolated compounds on the viability of macrophage (RAW 264.7) cells at different concentration (3.9–500 μg/mL). Error bars represent the standard error mean of three measurements.

Fig. 6. Protective effect of the isolated compounds on hydrogen peroxide induced mortality of macrophage (RAW 264.7) cells evaluated by MTT assay. *** represent significant difference between test and control at p < 0.05.

heading.emphasis: 4.7. Cytoprotective effects against H2O2 medicated cytotoxicity

subSection.paragraph: The confluent monolayer of RAW 264.7 cells (4 × 105) were incubated with different concentrations of the isolated compounds ( 7.81–125 mg /mL) for 1 h. Further, the cells were treated with H2O2 (3.0 mM) and maintained at 37 ◦ C with 5% CO2 for 12 h. Cells were then washed and inhibitory effects of the compounds on H2O2 induced cytotoxicity was
evaluated by measuring cell mortality using MTT assay at 570 nm .
